Award.AbstractNarration:
An example of a system studied in classical mechanics is the motion of a small satellite under the gravitational influence of planets. Historically, symplectic geometry grew out of studying situations such as this, in which the collection of all possible positions and momenta of the system (phase space) was seen to have the structure of a special space known as a symplectic manifold. Physical laws, like conservation of energy, then gave rise to models of the systems as dynamical systems on submanifolds of phase space corresponding to different energy levels. Modern symplectic methods have established deep connections between global properties of symplectic manifolds and the associated dynamics on a special class of energy levels, namely contact-type hypersurfaces, but have thus far proved to be of rather limited use for a general energy level. This project aims to rectify this deficiency and use global symplectic techniques to study dynamics on arbitrary energy levels by analyzing a generalized class of curves, known as feral pseudoholomorphic curves.

This project concerns research at the interface of geometric analysis, symplectic topology, and dynamical systems. The key idea is the use of a certain newly defined class of infinite Hofer-energy pseudoholomorphic curves, namely feral curves, to study Hamiltonian flows on prescribed energy surfaces in symplectic manifolds of arbitrary dimension and certain volume-preserving flows on three-manifolds in general. More specifically, the aim is to study these curves and their properties and to use them to establish non-minimality of a wide range of volume preserving flows in dimension three. A further aim is to study the generic asymptotic limit of such feral curves and to determine whether or not symplectic field theory admits an extension to symplectic manifolds with generic smooth boundary. Successful completion of this research has the potential to solve the volume-preserving Gottschalk conjecture, broadly extend symplectic field theory, and possibly yield key new insights on low dimensional differential topology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An example of a system studied in classical mechanics is the motion of a small satellite under the gravitational influence of planets. Historically, symplectic geometry grew out of studying situations such as this, in which the collection of all possible positions and momenta (phase space) was seen to have the structure of a special space known as a symplectic manifold. Physical laws, like conservation of energy, then gave rise to models of the systems as dynamical systems on submanifolds of phase space corresponding to different energy levels. Modern symplectic methods have established deep connections between global properties of symplectic manifolds and the associated dynamics on a special class of energy levels, namely contact-type hypersurfaces, but have thus far proved to be of rather limited use for a general energy level. This project aims to rectify this deficiency and use global symplectic techniques to study dynamics on arbitrary energy levels by analyzing a generalized class of curves, known as feral pseudoholomorphic curves.

This project concerned research at the interface of geometric analysis, symplectic topology, and dynamical systems. The key idea was to define and use of a certain novel class of infinite-energy pseudoholomorphic curves, namely feral curves, to study Hamiltonian flows on prescribed energy surfaces in symplectic manifolds of arbitrary dimension and certain volume-preserving flows on three-manifolds more generally.  In the past several decades, the use of finite energy curves as a means to study Hamiltonian dynamics has been extremely fruitful and has led to many important results.  Unfortunately, by their nature such curves only limit to a finite union of periodic orbits, and thus are somewhat limited in regards to which dynamical features they can detect.  By comparison, the feral curves discovered and developed by the PI have fewer restrictions, and in particular they can (and sometimes do) converge to closed sets which are invariant under the Hamiltonian flow. In a reasonable sense, these sets are characterized by the property that they contain a trajectory which does not "wander around" the entirety of the energy level.

A major outcome of this research was to develop feral curve theory and use it to establish that every non-empty smooth compact regular Hamiltonian energy level in R4 is not minimal.  Put more simply, we proved that in real Euclidean four-space, there exist a large class of Hamiltonian energy levels for which there necessarily exists a trajectory which does not "wander" around the entirety of the energy level.  This result fully answered one case of a question posed by Michael Herman in his 1998 ICM talk and made significant progress on the sixty-year-old Gottschalk Conjecture.  Additionally, it opened an entirely new line of research by establishing the existence and properties of feral curves.  This line of research will continue far beyond the duration of this grant.
